projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

figure.p: Currant verba licet manus eſt velecior illis. Nondum lingua ſuum dextra percegit Opus
By theiſe incomparable Contractions á Sentence is Writt as ſoone as A Word: Alowed by Authority and paſt the two Univerſitys with great aprobation and aplauſe Invented and taught by IEREMIAH RICH.
VERA EFFIGIES SAMUELIS BOTLEY: Ano 16 • 4 〈…〉 AMPLIAT ATATIS STATIUM SIBI VIR BON U.S. HOC EST VIVERE BIS VITA POSSE PRIORI FRVI

Arts faire disclosing bud peeps out and showes, Virtues Bloſsomes early blowes; Love, Ingenuity, whose end drew nigh Disputed long, where they should burred lye: At last being lost, this bosome made appear, Art, love, wit, virtue, are entombed heere. IR

figure.q: HONI SOIT QVI MAL Y PENSE.
figure.figDesc: royal blazon or coat of arms

figure.p: MAXIMUM in MINIMO OR Mr Ieremiah Rich's Pen's Dexterity Compleated.
BEING The Plaineſt & Eaſieſt Method of Writing Short-hand.
To which are added the Terms, of ye Law Compleat in Character and at length, Never done till now
London: Printed for Edmund Parke at the Bible and Crown in Lambard ſtreet near Stocks Market

div.p: MAXIMUM in MINIMO: OR, Mr. Jeremiah Rich's PEN's DEXTERITY COMPLEATED.
BEING The Plaineſt and Eaſieſt METHOD of Writing SHORT-HAND.
To which are added, The Terms of the Law Compleat in Characters and at length.
By SAMUEL BOTLEY.

p.hi: The Whole curiouſly Engrav'd on Thirty Copper-Plates.

div.p: LONDON: Printed for EDMUND PARKER at the Bible and Crown in Lombard-Street near Stocks-Market. (Price 1. s. 6 d.)
Lately Publiſh'd, The London New Method and Art of Teaching Children to Spell and Read. Price Bound 6d.

Note that the Alphabet (1) and the prepoſitions and Terminations (2) be very perfectly learned by hart, each lettor in the Alphabet ſtands for the words which are writ againſt it (3) ſhowes what words we uſe (e) in. and (3½) ſhows when (e) is ſuperfluous it may be laſt out (4) ſhows the places of the other fower vowels and a little behind ſtands for (s) and a daſh turned either up or downe in the middle of a word ſtands for (r) and that two ſhorthand (oo) ſtands for (pl) And note that if any word begin with a ſingle, or ̄ double, or treble conſonant and end with a vowel, you muſt write your conſonant and ſet your tittle in the place of the Vowel

table.head: 1 The Alphabet.
2 The Prepoſitions and Terminations.
3 How words muſt be writ by (e)
4 The places of the other fower vowels

div.p: The (5) ſhowes if words begin or end, or begin and end with a double conſonant, you muſt joyne your double conſonants together, obſerving to ſet your diſjunctives yt follow ye vowel in ye place of ye vowel (6) to begin and end words (7) ſhowes how to abreviate words by caſting out ſuperfluous lettors as (y) after (a) and (w) after (o) and (w) before (r) and (h) when it follows (w) and (gh) and (ugh) when they come together (8) ſhows you yt all words which begins with (c) unleſs (h) follows the (c) muſt be changed for (k) or (s) according to its ſound, but if in any word (ch) begins it then your character in ye Alphabet is (c) and (i) when it comes as a conſonant muſt be changed for (g) & (ph) muſt be changd for (f) & (e) muſt be left out when it comes before (m, n, l,) f, s, x, r, and after (d, b, p, t, g.

table.head: 5 words with double conſonants
6 begining and ending of words
7 how to a breviate words by
8 caſting out ſuperfluous lettors

div.p: Note that (1) shews how long words muſt be writ by the Prepoſitions and if you have a Prepoſition to begin the word and no mark for the Termination of the word you muſt end itt with the letters (2) shews if you have a Termination and not a prepoſition you muſt begin the word with the letters and Ioyne the Termination (as in account; amount, aſent, amounting, intent, and note that (n) drawne from the end of a word denotes (ing and if you have a-Prepoſition and Termination and no letter between then Ioyn them together (As) conſent, content, Temptation, and if a Vowel comes between the Prepoſition and Termination, Set the Termi: in the place of the Vowel as comition, comotion, and alwaies where the Prepo: and Termi: does not take hold of all the word make it up by the letters (Thus) condition, preſumptiō, and note (3) is ſet downe 8 double conſonants to be got by heart and (3 ½) note if a word begin with a Vowel write the Vowel and Ioyne the next conſonant to it

table.head: 1 Words by the Prepoſitions
2 and Terminations
3 Double conſonants to be got by heart
4 the Table of Ideas and Simbolicall Characters
5 for words and Sentences

row.cell: Chriſt at the right hand of God
even at the right hand of God

div.p: Note that theſe rules alone brings you to write any maner of diſcourſe without any more help and for the Simbolicall Characters you need not fear to get them by heart; for do but write them and you have them; For I Affirm) they are ſo far from burdening, that they teach the art of Memory more exact than the Egyption Hyerogliphicks — Note that your times of learning be firſt in morning and the laſt work at night by which you will retaine it freſh in your Memory and that you learn but a little at one time and that perfectly never more than one houre at a time to write, for when you take itt by little and little it comes eaſily; learn to make fine Penns and ſmall Characters you muſt write conſtantly by rule never mix long hand with Short, but if at firſt you cannot write all be ſhure you write Sentences and read them ſoon after you have writ them; let your book be but 2 inches

table.head: 6 broad when it is open and by
7 that means you may break of at the end of
8 any Sentence when you pleaſe and read itt

row.cell: there is nothing in the world
from one end of the world to the other

table.head: 9 with much more eaſe

div.p: The next thing and that wherin the curioſity of this Art conſiſteth in above others, are the rules of Contractions, which lye to your Veiw, and you muſt learne theire places as you did the places of the Vowells the firſt Rule is expreſt by one tittle the ſecond rule by two, the third rule by three tittles the fourth rule by one tittle under another and the fift is to expreſs the word _____ more by Ading a tittle more either to the 3d or 4th rules, as for Axample to write to come to god your mark for god is thus (y) ſet a tittle on the left hand thus (y) to depart from Chriſt (x) to dpart from the Nation (n)

table.head: 1 The Rules of Contraction to write a Sentence as soone as a word

row.cell: More of the love of God
More of the beauty of Chriſt

table.head: 2 The XII Rules of Contractions by the Alphabet

row.cell: For the sake of any Perſon 6

table.head: 5 A little under the Subſtantive-Signifyes to — Vnderſtand

To Vnderſtand the Mercy of God
To Vnderſtand the lawes of ye lord
To Vnderſtand the power of faith
A tittle over ye Adjective Signifyes to lay hould on
To lay hould on the Mercy of God
To lay hould on the love of God through Chriſt

table.head: 6 A little underneath the Adjective is to undervalid

row.cell: To Vndervalu the love of god
To Vndervalu the mercy of god
To Vndervalu the fear of god
To Vndervalu the people of god
To Vndervalu the Children of god
To Vndervalu the lawes of the lord

table.head: 7 if the ſentence begins with this you muſt turne the Tittles on one ſide this

row.cell: This is not the worſhip of god
This is not the wiſdome of god
Theiſe are not the people of god
This is not to run to god
Theise are not the men of the world
This is not the happineſs of a Child of god

row.cell: God will not give his sonn
God will not give his love
God will not give his mercy
God will not give his ſpirit

table.head: 1 how to Contract about the firſt rule

the congregation of Saints that com to god
when a man departs from god
a soule that comes to lay hould on the mercyes of God

table.head: 2 your (8) and () must be placed about the 2 rule

to be the Servants of god
to be the Children of god
to be the sants of god
to be a daughter of god
he his an eminent servant of god
he his an eminent Saint of god
he is an eminent child of god

to put in queſtion the love of god

this is the wiſdom of god

this is the feare of the lord
theise are the daughters of god
this is the worſhip of god
this is the love of god

table.head: 5 how to expreſs a double contractiō by two letters of the alphabet

row.cell: To be mercifull as god is mercifull
to be holy as god is holy
to be humble as chriſt was humble
to be happy as the saints of god are happy
to be negligent as the world is negligent
to be miſerable as the world is miſerable

table.head: 6 how to expreſs (from) betweene two subſtantives

row.cell: he that departs from god goes to the divill

table.head: 7 a ſtroak drawne from the Subſtantive to the right hand is to be joyned

row.cell: To be joyned to the people of god
to be joyned to the saints of god
to be joyned in love to the sonn of god
to be joyned to the children of god
to be joyned to the servants of god
to be joyned in love to thoſe that are not the people of god
to be joyned to the people of the world

table.head: 8 a ſtroak quite through is to imbrace

row.cell: To imbrace the people of god
to imbrace the love of the sonn of god
to imbrace the croſs of Chriſt
to imbrace the croſs of the world
to imbrace thoſe that are not the peopl of the world

table.head: 1 Abreviacons upon the letter () ()

row.cell: By the wiſdome of the King
By the love of the Sonn of God

row.cell: Before the eyes of the lord

table.head: 3 a double distance signifies (be it far from)

row.cell: Be it far from the people that love god
Be it far from a Child of god

table.head: 4 How to Expreſs a Queſtion asked

row.cell: Is this the wisdome of god
Is this the worship of god
Are these the Saints of god
Are these the men of the world
Is this to presume to come to lay hould on the mercy of god through Chriſt

table.head: 5 The place of () in a contraction

row.cell: To be doubtfull of the love of god
the depth of the mercy of god

div.p: An aproved receipt for good Ink /

(Take hafe a pound of Gaules groſsly pounded and a quarter of a pound of Gum-arabeck and halfe a quarter of a pound of Greene Copperas, put theis with three pints of Raine water in an earthen pott and ſtir it two or three times a day, and in a weeke it will be fitt for use, if you would have a gloſs on it put in halfe a pint of Rich malaga wine you may double your quantity as you see occation

table.head: 6 A Tittle by the Substantive turns (d) into a deſi •

row.cell: A Saint deſires to be delivered from the world
A Saint deſires to be delivered from the wrath of god
A Saint deſires to be delivered from the power of sinn
A Saint desires to be delivered from the feare of death

table.head: 7 The fift place of (d)

row.cell: A ſaint deſires nothing on this ſide god
A ſaint deſires nothing on this ſide the glory of god
A ſaint deſires nothing on this ſide the love of god through Christ

The moſt choice of the people of god
The most choice of the men of the world
To chuse to ſuffer for chriſt
The Charity of the true Church to chuse to ſuffer for the saints of god

table.head: 9 How to contract great-numbers by (e)

row.cell: A saint is a 1000 times better then the world
A saint is a 1000 times nearer to god
A 1000 times further of from god

div.p:
A short Rule by one another
to undestand one another
to undestand the happineſs of
to love one another
Two different wajes to expreſs the preposition (Con)
It is contrary to any thing / . To stand in contradicōn against / .

list.item: it is contrary to the laws of God
to stand in con: agt scripture
to stand in con: agt the laws of God

div.p: To oppose any thing / . To stand in Opposition against / .

list.item: to oppose the people of God
to stand in Oposition agt ye laws of God
to stand in Oposition agt ye feare of death

div.p:
When a long and Tedious word comes often in a sermon— or speech, expreſs it only by the Preposition
Incomprehensible
representation

If you have a contracōn and an Idea comes both at on time leave out your contracōn and set the Idea in the room of it
a little life of grace
a little life of faith

The Magnitude of any thing is exprest by the bigneſs of your disjunctive contracōn
The great want of faith
The great subtilty of sathan
The great mercy of God

All degrees exprest by the placeing your disjunctive
in the world are vanities upon vanities ()
Iob had loſs upon loſs ()
the divil has subtilty upon subtiltie ()

div.head: The whole Terms of the Law in Mr. Rich's Character. Compleated: Never done before by any till now, by S: Botley
